B1.desc: Understand how OpenShift’s security layers protect applications and data by default, including the hardened OS and basic cluster controls.
B1.relevance: Red Hat Enterprise Linux CoreOS (RHCOS), OpenShift default security settings.

B2.desc: Know the basics of user access control in OpenShift, including how keycards (RBAC) regulate who can do what in the cluster.
B2.relevance: OpenShift Role-Based Access Control (RBAC), OAuth authentication.

B3.desc: Learn how container guardrails (SecurityContextConstraints) limit what containers can do inside OpenShift.

B4.desc: Understand network walls inside the cluster (NetworkPolicies) that control which applications can talk to each other.

B5.desc: Know how secrets like passwords and API keys are safely stored and protected in OpenShift.

B6.desc: Understand why only trusted container images should be run and the basics of checking image safety.
B6.relevance: OpenShift internal registry, image signing and scanning.

B7.desc: Learn how audit logs act as security cameras, tracking who did what and when in the cluster.
B7.relevance: OpenShift Audit Logging and Cluster Logging.

B8.desc: Be familiar with add-ons that enhance OpenShift security like Compliance Operator and Security Profiles Operator.

B9.desc: Understand workload isolation including why containers shouldn’t run as cluster admins or root users, and why they can only bind to non-privileged ports (above 1024).
B9.relevance: Least privilege container execution, SCC policies, container networking constraints.

B10.desc: Know how encryption protects data in transit and at rest inside OpenShift.
B10.relevance: TLS encryption, etcd encryption, KMS integration.

I1.desc: Perform threat modeling to find and reduce security risks in OpenShift applications and workloads.
I1.relevance: OpenShift security architecture, SCCs, Network Policies.

I2.desc: Manage advanced user access control with fine-grained permissions and service accounts.

I3.desc: Configure and enforce workload security policies to prevent privilege escalation and unauthorized host access.

I4.desc: Design and apply network policies to limit communications between applications and reduce attack surface.

I5.desc: Integrate security checks into CI/CD pipelines to catch vulnerabilities early in the software supply chain.

I6.desc: Manage secret lifecycles securely, including encryption, rotation, and controlled access.

I7.desc: Analyze audit logs and monitoring data to detect security incidents or suspicious behaviors.

I8.desc: Automate compliance checks against industry standards to maintain cluster security posture.

I9.desc: Apply advanced workload restrictions using custom security profiles for syscall and access control.

I10.desc: Configure and enforce admission control policies to govern cluster resource usage and security.
I10.relevance: Gatekeeper via RHACM, OpenShift Admission Controllers.

A1.desc: Lead OpenShift cluster security design and governance across multiple teams and projects.
A1.relevance: OpenShift security best practices, governance models.

A2.desc: Develop and automate security policies and compliance workflows using GitOps and Infrastructure as Code.
A2.relevance: GitOps, Policy as Code, Compliance Operator.

A3.desc: Architect multi-tenant network segmentation and enforce strict communication boundaries.
A3.relevance: Advanced Network Policies, service mesh security.

A4.desc: Implement runtime security monitoring and threat detection to respond to attacks quickly.

A5.desc: Lead incident response activities using audit data, threat intelligence, and forensic analysis.
A5.relevance: OpenShift Audit Logs, RHACS Threat Detection.

A6.desc: Design secure supply chains including image provenance, signing, and vulnerability management.
A6.relevance: Image signing, Quay, Red Hat UBI images.

A7.desc: Automate cluster-wide security enforcement and remediation using policy agents and custom controllers.

A8.desc: Mentor teams on security best practices and foster a security-first culture.

A9.desc: Design cryptography, logging, and observability for maximum security and auditability.

A10.desc: Implement zero-trust workload identity and confidential computing to protect sensitive workloads.

responsibilities.R1: Design applications using threat modeling to reduce security risks on OpenShift.
responsibilities.R2: Use OpenShift service accounts and Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) for secure access management.
responsibilities.R3: Store secrets securely using OpenShift Secrets and enable encryption.
responsibilities.R4: Integrate vulnerability scanning and security testing in CI/CD pipelines using OpenShift Pipelines.
responsibilities.R5: Keep dependencies and container images updated to fix vulnerabilities and avoid deprecated software.
responsibilities.R6: Follow OpenShift security best practices, such as running non-root containers and applying network policies.
responsibilities.R7: Collaborate with security teams on auditing, monitoring, and responding to security events.
responsibilities.R8: Configure Security Context Constraints (SCCs), RBAC, and Network Policies to enforce cluster security.
responsibilities.R9: Harden OpenShift nodes and perform patch management using OpenShift tooling.
responsibilities.R10: Integrate OpenShift audit logs with monitoring and Security Information and Event Management (SIEM) systems.
responsibilities.R11: Conduct vulnerability scanning and remediation using Advanced Cluster Security (RHACS).
responsibilities.R12: Automate compliance checks with Compliance Operator aligned to industry security standards.
responsibilities.R13: Embed security controls and best practices in CI/CD pipelines, collaborating closely with development teams.
responsibilities.R14: Provide training and documentation on OpenShift platform security and best practices.
responsibilities.R15: Design secure, scalable OpenShift architectures integrating compliance and monitoring capabilities.
responsibilities.R16: Lead governance and policy definition aligned with organizational security standards and Zero Trust principles.
responsibilities.R17: Automate vulnerability assessments and remediation workflows within OpenShift environments.
responsibilities.R18: Mentor teams on secure design, security best practices, and continuous security improvement.
responsibilities.R19: Create and manage secure, automated OpenShift deployment pipelines incorporating SAST, DAST, and vulnerability scanning.
responsibilities.R20: Manage infrastructure as code (IaC) securely, including container builds and deployment.
responsibilities.R21: Enforce security policies through admission controllers such as Gatekeeper integrated with OpenShift.
responsibilities.R22: Design and secure OpenShift network infrastructure using Network Policies, SDN, and VPNs.
responsibilities.R23: Implement encryption for data in transit and at rest within and outside OpenShift clusters.
responsibilities.R24: Monitor and manage network traffic for anomalies and mitigate Denial of Service (DoS) attacks.
responsibilities.R25: Conduct threat modeling, runtime security monitoring, and incident response using RHACS and audit logs.
responsibilities.R26: Implement Zero Trust security models for workloads and manage workload isolation effectively.
responsibilities.R27: Manage OpenShift security infrastructure including Identity and Access Management (IAM), SIEM, EDR, and policy enforcement.
responsibilities.R28: Maintain and update security policies and documentation, ensuring operational security and compliance.
responsibilities.R29: Coordinate with Product Lifecycle Management to align security initiatives with product goals.

Application Developer.description: Build secure containerized applications on OpenShift, using trusted images, secrets, RBAC, and secure development practices.

Platform Operator.description: Deploy, operate, and harden OpenShift clusters, enforcing security policies, managing access, logging, compliance, and encryption.

DevSecOps Engineer.description: Secure CI/CD pipelines and enforce policy throughout the application lifecycle, bridging development and security through automation.

Security Architect.description: Design security strategies and architectures for OpenShift, driving governance, compliance, supply chain risk reduction, and zero-trust across teams.

Network & Infrastructure Engineer.description: Design and secure OpenShift networking and infrastructure, including segmentation, encryption, and logging.
